you can try transposing your weight with the swapaxis layer.

Is the data shuffled? By default the csv read data in as it is and can read more size than the memory size, and did not shuffle the data by default. The index is not used during training.

As an alternative, MXNet do accept numpy array as input and I guess that is the easiest way if the data fit into memory.
batch size looks too big. learning rate is probably to big/small.

shape inference is only run on cpu.
An easy solution is to add a flag in TorchModeleParam to specify if you want shape inference to run on gpu, but this own allow selecting which gpu to run on.

It's for syncing with engine, which is asynchronous. You don't need to explicitly call it for most of the use cases.

Great work, Let us aim to merge it in this weekend.

Please make a list of changes and major files you added, as some of the change corresponds to refactoring.

Some comments:
- The executor manager seems to be a refactoring, and separation of manager into two parts, which I think is fine
- Do you guys think if sym_gen can be actually merged with symbol? to use callable as a way to distinguish between the things.
- Consider move the bucket API example to a separate folder, or at least create one at LSTM part. Current example is great for integrated testing, but bad for users to get started, as things get too deep and there are a few additional dependencies.

`wait_to_read` means block until results of the array is available. Usually you don't have to call it. 
Note that if you copy data out, e.g.

```
b = a.tonumpy()
```

`wait_to_read` is automatically called. There is only one  reason you need to call this function: you are doing a loop, and you do not want to go too fast. Because mxnet is an async engine, and if there is no blockings, wait_to_read can be called so not too many ops will swarm the engine. 

Of course, even this can be eliminated if we limit the ops can be pushed to engine(which we did not yet do)

In normal cases, after each iteration, usually we will do

```
pred = exec.output[0].copyto(mx.cpu()).asnumpy()
logging.info("evaluation=%g", evaluate(pred, label))
```

This means the blocking is already introduced and not explicit wait to read is needed

One question, is the shared exec currently cached in a dict(so it can be reused when facing same bucket)? I ask this question because it depends on the overhead of creating an exec. 

If it is small, then on the fly creating is fine, and even no sharing between execs is OK, as long as we destruct the exec and releases the memory. The sharing strategy probably need caching, so we avoid "re-compile" the execs and directly reuse the buckets that is already there. Of course the pure-imperative api and caching are two strategies that can be switched from on to another
Yes, shared exec is cached in a dict. Will address other questions shortly.

@tqchen The main changes are very minimum, most of the code here are examples (one trivial MNIST example and one word-rnn ptb language model example). Basically, the original `DataParallelExecutorManager` is refactored into two part: a `DataParallelExecutorGroup` is a group of executors living on different devices. All executors in a group correspond to the same symbol. The original  `DataParallelExecutorManager` now keeps reference to a `DataParallelExecutorGroup`. The _current_ group is switched every time a data batch is loaded. Executor groups are created for different configuration (`bucket_key`), and they will be sharing memory with existing executor groups. The created executors are cached in a dict.

The current modifications are compatible with the existing API -- the existing code that does not use bucketing API could continue to run without any problem.

The examples are currently buried in corners. I'm planning to write some doc about how to use the bucketing API.

Several issues:
- Currently Travis CI seem to be broken, it has been claiming that gcc-4.8 is not found.
- The current ptb rnn example runs rather slowly. It is still quite slow after disabling bucketing and using trivial data loading. I'm not sure whether it is due to the weird computing environment in our lab cluster or because of some slow code.
- The `Monitor`s are installed in executors. For the current case, we will have a lot of executors, some of them will be executed more frequently than the others. I just raise an NotImplemented exception currently if the user attempt to install monitors when bucketing is used. Maybe there could be better way to handle this.

I found another reason may cause this problem: screen

I always launch notebook(jupyter) in a screen session, and I'm not aware that screen will unset LD_LIBRARY_PATH env var, so the library load will fail

To fix this, add content below to ~/.screenrc:
`setenv LD_LIBRARY_PATH /usr/local/cuda-7.5/lib64(or your lib path)`

then restart screen sessions to take effect

It looks normal. Your accuracy layer is computing the accuracy that EVERY label is predicting correctly, which is effectively 2^9=512 class classification, and the training process should start with a low accuracy.

It seems like the problem is due to the KVStore was not correctly created for os.environ['DMLC_ROLE'] = 'server'. The same error would happen if I assign it to a irrelevant string. But setting it to "worker" doesn't cause any problem. Does anyone know if there is a method to get some error message from kvstore.create() function?

Hi @yuzcccc, yes I tried cifar10 with inception and ResNet with different batch_size (128, 256, 512) and problem remains the same. In every case  the Volatile GPU-Util adds up to 100% only.

Hi @RishabGargeya , I got the same issue and fixed it. Are you compiling on a machine that actually have a GPU? Or you're just compiling with CUDA library (which is usually the case in super computers)? It was not looking for libcuda.so but libcuda.so.1, which should locate in /usr/local/lib. (Try `ldd lib/libmxnet.so and you will see it`) You have to compile it and run it on a machine with a GPU on it.
CuDNN 3 and 4 are both supported

The reason is the parameter of Xavier is not correct. Try use mx.init.Xavier(factor_type="in", rnd_type="gaussian", magnitude=2.0) for MSRA initialization. It works well for the network with BN. For alexnet, you need to divide the output by 128 in the FC layer.
Solved this issue by setting the environment variable before calling the file

Hi @shenxiul, I am indeed running mxnet using shared resources on a supercomputer. I was actually able to run mxnet when directly accessing a gpu node but was unable to call `import mxnet` when on a cpu (getting the above error). I compiled mxnet as above and was hoping to conduct some tests on a cpu independently. How were you able to fix the issue? The /usr/local/lib directory seems to be empty and I don't have permission to write to it.

@RishabGargeya , this is due to the implementation of mxnet. Once we compile it with CUDA option, whenever we are loading libmxnet.so, it has to find libcuda.so.1, in other words it must be run on a node with GPU on it. We can still use CPU mode to let it runs on CPU only, but must on a machine that has GPU installed. That's might be a potential flaw, can we open another issue or PR stating this problem and close this issue?

Are you interested in verifying this and submit a PR?

if do not consider the backward operation, it is easy to make mxnet use cudnn_v2.
In mxnet, BN layer learns the gamma (i.e. the slope), so it is equivalent to BN + scale layer in caffe

Hmm I just realized this part... Thanks @winstywang ! I'm working on resolving it now. Can I take that in mxnet we don't have such scale layer? I know for this specific problem we don't need it, just curious.
its equivalent to a 1x1 conv layer with n groups and without bias right?
@piiswrong , awesome idea! But it's 1x1 conv layer _with_ bias, right, as in BN layer we have both beta(bias) and gamma(scale)? what's the "groups" you mentioned?
Hi @shenxiul, of course. We can close this issue and open another one.
@pluskid  @piiswrong  Ok
so I change the doc
@winstywang I see, thanks. Seems that we should change the params for Xavier.
Could you provide a script that reproduce this error? It's hard to figure out what exactly you have done.
@shenxiul each conv kernel should only handle one input channel
@pluskid I think the default data parallel mechanism will indeed slowdown the LSTM
@shenxiul  The scaling layer you mentioned can be easily added, if necessary. Because the backend used mshadow expression template, and what we need is basically a simplified version of BN.

Alternatively, we can add a broadcast operator and simply make it as 

```
out  = in * broadcast(bias, shape=out.shape, axis = 3)
```

@tqchen I'm not sure if it is necessary at this point, because to convert ResNet pre-trained model we only need scaling and bias added in BN. But it will be a good solution for converting caffe model in general, otherwise we might end up with some dirty workarounds all the time. I just want to make sure one thing, our BN layer only have scale term but not bias term?
You will need to call `infer_shape` to get the shape of an output.
MXNet's BN layer have both scale and bias term, with the scale term can be optionally disabled via `fix_gamma` parameter

@tqchen I see. So if we don't have scale layer, we basically have to parse prototxt to check if BN connects with a scale layer and then save the parameters in scale layer into BN layer? It sounds not quite decent and if BN doesn't connect with Scale layer we don't have the option to fix bias...
I get what you mean, you are more than welcomed to add a BroadcastMul Layer to mxnet, that resolves the issue.
@piiswrong can you start an initial proposal of what we have? I think a python code will do
